cyclone.name: HARVEY
cyclone.current_location: about 115 miles SE of Corpus Christi, Texas
cyclone.trajectory: Tracking northwest toward the middle Texas coast, then forecast to stall/meander for several days just inland or near the coast before drifting back offshore early next week toward the upper Texas-Louisiana coast.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: middle Texas coast in the Rockport–Port O’Connor area

weather_observation.watch_coast: None in effect for upper Texas coast at this time.
weather_observation.warning_coast: Tropical Storm Warning is posted from North of Sargent to High Island, Texas (ends about 50 mi SW of Port Arthur).
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Texas coast from Port Mansfield to High Island already under warnings, with impacts expected to spread into the upper Texas and southwest Louisiana coasts, including Port Arthur.
weather_observation.storm_surge_above_3_feet: Marginal – guidance indicates 2–4 ft possible, unlikely to greatly exceed 3 ft at Port Arthur.
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (39–57 mph) possible late Sunday through Monday with gusts near gale force.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Storm surge of 2–4 ft above ground possible near high tide for areas from Jamaica Beach to High Island which includes Sabine Pass entrance affecting Port Arthur’s approaches.
weather_observation.rainfall: 10–20 inches of rain with locally higher totals possible, producing life-threatening flash flooding around Port Arthur and Sabine–Neches waterways.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Isolated tornadoes in outer rainbands; extended period of high seas and dangerous rip currents; prolonged operational disruption due to Harvey’s slow movement.
